description: From Middle English lace, laace, las, from Old French las, from Vulgar Latin *laceum, based on Latin laqueus. Doublet of lasso.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A light fabric containing patterns of holes, usually built up from a single thread. Wp
examples: Our English dames are much given to the wearing of very fine and costly laces.

entries.meaning: (countable) A cord or ribbon passed through eyelets in a shoe or garment, pulled tight and tied to fasten the shoe or garment firmly. Wp
examples: your laces are untied, do them up!

entries.meaning: A snare or gin, especially one made of interwoven cords; a net.
(slang, obsolete) Spirits added to coffee or another beverage.

description: From Middle English lacen, lasen, from Old French lacer, lacier, lasser, lachier, from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: lace (third-person singular simple present laces, present participle lacing, simple past and past participle laced)

examples: When Jenny's stays are newly laced.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To add alcohol, poison, a drug or anything else potentially harmful to (food or drink).

examples: The Gond  [â€¦]  picked up a trail of the Karela, the vine that bears the bitter wild gourd, and laced it to and fro across the temple door.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To interweave the spokes of a bicycle wheel.
(transitive) To beat; to lash; to make stripes on.
(transitive) To adorn with narrow strips or braids of some decorative material.
